questions.question_text: Which two statements are true about DB Systems? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: Answer is AC. DG can be configured as a Cross Region for DR. https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Database/Tasks/usingdataguard.htm

C. Automatic backup schedules are fixed. 15D, 30D, 45 Days etc... etc. i think partially right the C. 
A is okay right. between regions yes. its just need to be peered only.
A is wrong because Data guard should use the same VCN for the DB systems.
C & D is the correct answer

comments.content: so A and B are wrong, only leave C&D as answers...

discussion.content:
A is wrong. DG across regions is a manual configuration.

https://www.oracle.com/in/database/database-management-cloud-faq.html

Can I set up Data Guard across Oracle Cloud Infrastructure regions?
Yes, you can set up Data Guard across regions, but the Database Cloud Service Data Guard feature currently does not support it. You can manually set up Data Guard across regions by logging on to your host and using DGMGRL. You must enable an internet gateway on the primary and standby DB system VCN for Data Guard to transport logs across regions. Learn more about DGMGRL.
DG is a regional service. Answer is B and C

choices.A: Data Guard as a Service is offered between regions.
choices.C: You have full control over the automatic backup schedule and retention periods.
choices.B: You cannot manage the database as sys/sysdba.
choices.D: You can manage Oracle database initialization parameters at a global level.

questions.question_text: Which two statements are true about DB Systems in Oracle Cloud Infrastructure? (Choose two.)

choices.D: The database and backups are encrypted by default.
choices.B: Customers have no control over database patching.
choices.A: Customers can consolidate multiple database homes on a single virtual machine database host.
choices.C: Customers can manage the TDE Wallet after DB Systems are provisioned.

discussion.content: Terraform providers are written in the Go programming language. Answer is B

questions.question_text: In which language are Terraform and Terraform providers written?
Why are two subnets required to create a public load balancer when additional subnets are often used for back-end servers? (Choose two.)

choices.A: Routing is simpler when the load balancer is not in the same subnet as the back-end server.
choices.D: Additional subnets for back-end servers allow for separate security lists for these servers.
choices.C: Additional subnets for back-end servers allow for separate route tables for these servers.
choices.B: Performance is higher when more subnets are used.

discussion.content:
The correct answer is CD. Performance isn't impacted by using two subnets. From the link given in the answer:

Your load balancer should always reside in a separate subnet than your application instances. This allows you to keep your application instances secured in private subnets while allowing public Internet traffic to the load balancer in the public subnets.

To add the public subnets to your VCN perform the following tasks:

Add a security list.
Add a route table.
Create the first and second subnets.

comments.content:
The primary routing scenario is for sending a subnet's traffic to destinations outside the VCN. A subnet has a single route table of your choice associated with it. All VNICs in that subnet are subject to the rules in the route table. The rules govern how the traffic leaving the subnet is routed.
https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Network/Tasks/managingroutetables.htm

Do we need a route table in the same VCN, i dont think so...basically route table is configured when implementing gateways like IGW , DRG, SGW and NATG becoz these gateways routes traffic out of the VCN, hence therefore no need for routing table.

discussion.content:
how performance related to subnets?
i think correct answer should be C and D
